commentBody:
Fearless Fosdick predicts:

This puzzle will be commented upon by scores of people who will say they didn't see the theme while they were doing it, didn't see it when they were finished, and didn't understand it even after reading the explanation.
Trivially easy to just brute force.
Didn‚Äôt spend a second trying to understand the theme before, during, or after. This was just a brute force solve.
Not having a good week. Got mixed up with Inter Borough Rapid Transit. Somehow that became IBT and ATAbI seemed fine

Ha - I had to go looking for where the third theme entry was, because I had been satisfied that Faith Hill could have made a perplexing philosophical song entitled ‚ÄúThis‚Äù:

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs perpetual bliss.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat is?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat is this?‚Äù

‚ÄúPerpetual bliss.‚Äù

This took me barely half of my average Thursday time and, in all honesty, I completely forgot there was even supposed to be a theme. I'm ignorant enough about Faith Hill that "THIS" sounds like a reasonable song title by itself. The only thing I couldn't figure out was what CASH IS was supposed to mean, but oh well. Less of an "aha!" theme and more of an "oh, alright" one.

A Thursday puzzle you can easily solve quicker than in Wednesday time and without ever considering the theme is not a true Thursday, is it?

I admit I was slightly puzzled by CASHIS for 'Money talks', but it did not prevent me from filling the grid. Not knowing the title of the Faith Hill song meant I never considered the answer as part of the theme (I just ignored it). Finally, I misread the clue for PENCILS as plural so the answer sort of made sense without [KIRT].

I was surprised to get ATARI from crosses: I know nothing about go (in fact I only vaguely remember ever hearing of a game with that name), but I've been a (video) gamer for almost 40 years, so I only associate ATARI with video games.

It was not a bad puzzle as such, and the construction can't have been easy, but personally I found it to be less difficult than I expect on a Thursday. Once I would have considered that a good thing, but these days I actually enjoy being slightly challenged by these puzzles.

Had last wish for 16A (end of year wish) üòß I'm not as dark as that makes me look! I was thinking of closing out the year with a wish like a it was a birthday ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è it made sense for a few mins...

The helpful thing to do here would be to link to SATIE‚Äôs Parade, where the typewriter comes through loud and educationally clear, but the responsible thing‚Äîthe altruistic thing‚Äîis always to link to the Gymnop√©dies and the Gnossiennes: For that one person who‚Äôs never heard Satie before and whose life won‚Äôt be the same now she has. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=wnacdOIoTBQ
Not my cup of tea.
A SKI LIFT, then downhill all the way.  One to enjoy on Christmas Day.  I don't mean to be SNIDE, but if you couldn't ICe this one, you may have spent too much time at THE BAR.

I have a new Thursday PB with this puzzle, even though I didn‚Äôt figure out the entire theme until after it was over. The cluing was extremely straightforward, especially the Downs, so even though some of the Across answers didn‚Äôt match the clues, I didn‚Äôt notice.

I had 3 daily PBs in 2024 ‚Äî one in January for a Friday, one in August for a Monday, and today.

I hope everyone is having a good holiday season!
Happy holidays to all!

Putting aside the theme, I really adored the debonair, urbane, neo-Weintraubian cleverness of the cluing and answers. And some of the little touches, like LOGOMANIA crossing OFF LABEL. Amused by coffeehouse beatniks for its stereotyping -- there were a lot of coffeehouse poets in NY and San Francisco (and parts in between) in the 50s and 60s who would be horrified to be lumped in with the beatniks. Frank O'Hara and John Ashbery read in the downtown scene, in coffeehouses and they'd be Howling with laughter to be linked to the "angelheaded hipsters burning for the ancient heavenly connection to the starry dynamo in the machinery of night." Minor kvetch.

And the theme was well done, brilliant that the first two could be entered without "getting" the ski lift: "This" works as a title, and "pencils" could be "bottoms" just as "trousers" and "capris" are. It's only when you get to "Cash is" that you know the game's afoot. I'd bet Ms. Dershowitz knew to do it that way. 

I wish the ski lifts could have been diagonal somehow, the way ski lifts are. These ski lifts look more like fork lifts, so that was a minor disappointment.  Despite that, I think this is Ms. Dershowitz's best puzzle yet. 

Good holidays to all you logo-maniacs out there! May you not suffer from logorrhea from eating too much caloric verbiage at your family gatherings this season. It can make you gassy for sure!
I liked the trick and it definitely helped with one or two of the answers.  Fun.

Ah Thursday.  You got me again. 

I guess if you ride the lift keeping the bar raised it looks somewhat like a Tetris block.  But use your bars people.  Falling is no joke.  And you don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs under the snow.

Not bad. The grid suggested a rebus, black squares use, or some other trickery, so this theme wasn't too hard to see after the revealer and weird answers to some clue. 

Clueing could have been better, and the puzzle could have been more difficult. 6/10.

I was a little perplexed for a moment after running into my first tricky section. Wondered how I was going to fit "THIS KISS" into four squares. The crosses got me to put THIS into those four, and then after a bit I noticed the elevation of the last part of it. That made it a tad easier to figure out what to do with the rest of the tricks when I ran across them.

Fun puzzle, nice trick. Thanks, Ella!

Once you come to the blog and peep the theme it obviously makes sense in retrospect and there is an element of respect to the designer. But during the puzzle it's just "that's not what that song is called but the puzzle is never wrong so I'm missing something" or "that's not what that phrase is but the puzzle is never wrong so I'm missing something". I'm truly not sure how to feel about it. Again. Respect to the cleverness of the theme but I would be surprised if more than the tiniest fraction figured it out. 

One area of the puzzle that really got me was MOIRA crossing IRAS. Having never seen the Handmaid's Tale (didn't have the proper streaming service at the time and then lost interest) and being Canadian (and therefore ignorant of certain American tax ephemera) this combo felt borderline impossible to get correct within the bounds of the puzzle. The other one was ironically the revealer where it crossed "gumshoe". I know a gumshoe is a detective but have never once seen it shortened to TEC.

Anyway. Good efforts all around but it would be nice if certain types of trivia were a little more crossable. Take care!
Agree with Deb - the theme slowly clicking into place for this one made it a pleasure to solve. Great puzzle

I finished the puzzle without ever understanding the theme. Does that make me bad at solving, or does that make the theme bad at presenting itself? The only entry that made me furrow my brow was the Faith Hill song‚Ä¶it should have been THIS KISS, but the specs and existing letters only allowed for THIS, so who am I to question?

PENCILS alone seemed like an acceptable response to ‚Äúclose fitting skirt‚Äù, and CASH IS was filled in through crosses, so I didn‚Äôt even notice the truncated expression. 

I expect more from a Thursday puzzle, but it‚Äôs Christmas, so in the spirit of the holiday I will not complain. Peace on earth, good will to all solvers, etc etc. Be careful on the slopes.

I enjoyed this one a lot. (Is it me, or are the crosswords just getting more clever with each passing day?)
I found the first theme entry right away and the key to theme nearly at the end. Nice clueing made for a breezy solve.
Thoroughly fun! Thanks, Ella!

Almost exactly my average time for Thursday, so in terms of difficulty this was on the right day of the week for me. I got the theme with a little help from Deb (I knew I had to lift something above the SKIs but not knowing the song and thinking ‚Äúpencil‚Äù seemed good enough on its own, I didn‚Äôt get the operation of the lift until I read the first part of the column). 

Speaking of ski lifts, glad I wasn‚Äôt on the gondola at Winter Park last Saturday when riders got stuck up in the air for five hours! This was much more fun than that. üö†
Sadly hangs a zero on the "Days since atari in Go has been compared to check in Chess" sign
I too immediately filled 33A with ELOPE. But soon realized it made 10D into something ‚Ä¶ unlikely to say the least.

Got wise to the theme just in time to be able to fix a problem in the north east corner. Maybe slightly easier Thursday than usual. I'm starting to remember these US brand names like now the bed maker as they tend to repeat. So that helps.
Smooth as freshly fallen snow.  No moguls.

Took me forever to understand the theme. I finally got it at PENCILS/KIRT, but it still took a lot of staring at the completed grid to see CASHIS/KING. Clever.
Overall a slightly easier than usual Thursday for me, but a pleasant fill nevertheless.

A belated Merry Christmas/insert your holiday of choice, to all. It‚Äôs Boxing Day here in the UK (the feast day of St Stephen), devoted to football or racing if your sports minded, or lolling on the sofa with cold turkey sandwiches if you‚Äôre me.
New Thursday PB. Appreciate the easy ride, still feel like a hungover walrus after yesterday‚Äôs feasting.

Not all that easy for me, and cheated a bit, but finally catching to the theme was a nice 'aha' moment and managed to work it all out after that. Did a lot of skiing as a kid at a ski hill just outside of town. That one did have a SKILIFT, but only the more affluent folks got to use it. The rest of us just used the ROPETOW. And that led me to one puzzle find today. It was an answer in that one but not part of the theme. Anyway.. a Thursday from September 29, 2011 by Ben Fish. That one had a circled letter in each of the four corners, and the letters in those circles were: P, L, U and S. No hint to the theme beyond that. And then four theme answers, each of them clued as "See Blurb" Those answers were: GRADEBONUS MATHSYMBOL NICEQUALITY POSITIVEEND Don't grasp the connection between 'blurb' and the four corners, but... whatever. Here's the Xword Info link for that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=9/29/2011&g=48&d=A Might put some other puzzle finds in replies. ...
Is it just me or was this puzzle easy to solve without knowing about, or caring about, any reference to ski lifts.

Don‚Äôt want to get too far over my skis this morning, but this puzzle gave me a lift! 

Seems like I might be in the minority today.
Two comments: (1) I've known a few older people in need of burping and (2) there's something fishy about one of those clues.

Perhaps AI can someday bring relief to those who chronically declare the puzzle far too easy for them: Individualized, computer-generated puzzles designed to ensure that everyone solves in exactly their average time, or occasionally a minute more so they can feel challenged, or sometimes a few minutes less so they can proclaim their intelligence. Technological nirvana for the status-conscious cruciverbalist. 

Until then, perhaps the NYT could add a button to autogenerate a complaint that the puzzle was too easy. Think of the time it would save!

For today, though, in the season of reflection and gratitude, perhaps we could relax and remember the puzzle is a game and every one is different from the last, and some necessarily will take longer than others, and we are lucky to have crosswords prepared at a level as consistently high as those in the NYT. 

Happy holidays to all!

Oh, crafty puzzle.  Crafty in two senses.

It took great craft just to build this grid:
‚Ä¢	It‚Äôs a tight theme.  After today‚Äôs theme answers that include IKS, if you don‚Äôt want to repeat names or words ending in IKS, there‚Äôs SHIKSA, and ‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm going blank.  Help?
‚Ä¢	Having three theme answers that take double turns greatly constricts the answer possibilities, and filling this in as cleanly as Ella did displays her virtuosity.
‚Ä¢	As does creating a grid design that accommodates this twisty-turny theme.

It also took great craft, as in cunning, to come across the term SKI LIFT, and envisage a theme that had SKI not only going upward, but taking the solver to a higher level to complete the theme answer.  Not to mention the cunning involved in creating a theme never used before in ANY of the major crossword venues.

I did like the theme echo in THE BAR, which reminded me of T-BAR, clued so often in Crosslandia as [Ski lift].

Ella, your puzzles are imaginative, playful, and, yes, crafty.  All of them.  Brava on today‚Äôs, and thank you for a most splendid outing!

Fun to discover BEATNIK in the puzzle. The"beat" generation post WWII and a coinage perhaps influenced by SPUTNIK the Russian satellite of that era and immortalized by Bob Denver playing Maynard G Krebs on "Dobie Gillis"

Like, Groovy, Man!
Hooray! Deb's back. That's a lift to my spirits.

‚ÄúCrosses will never fail you‚Äù: if you just believe this enough, you don‚Äôt need a ski lift to get over faith hill.

And in these days of brand-name plastic and crypto money,
CASHIS OFFLABEL.

Very clever Thursday puzzle. And all the SKI lifts were hidden in interesting long entries: ERIKSATIE, BEATNIKS, RUBIKSCUBES. (Very helpful to me that SATIE appeared in a recent puzzle.)

"Bass organs" for GILLS was cute too. 

Wasn't familiar with THISKISS or PENCILSKIRT, but seeing PENCILS for "Slim-fitting bottom" certainly let me know something tricky was afoot.

Liked this one quite a lot.
Loved this!  Thank you, Ella, for a fun seasonal theme.

Any puzzle that totally fools me -- and in a totally fair way -- gets a thankyou from me.  After seeing all three upward SKIs, I thought I was finished.  "That's a pretty dull Thursday," I thought.  Like many, I was satisfied that Faith Hill had recorded a song called "THIS," that CASHIS meant something and that slim-fitting bottoms were called PENCILS.  As happens so often, I am grateful to Deb for bringing me to the party.

Today I learned ATARI.  And I figured out the theme at the end of my solve.  An uplifting experience it was.  They really raised the bar for this one.  I'll make it my slalom promise to not make any more puns about this puzzle.  

Completed in 24% less time than average.

Flubbed the spelling of the composer's given name (ERIc) so spent a lot of time the end looking for that last LIFT but finally picked up my mistake.  Clever fun, just right for the post celebration morning.  Many thanks.

I found the word SKI in two other places but I'll be hanged if I can figure out what the lifts were. Usually you provide all the theme answers but didn't this time. Pray tell what are the other two lifts. Thank you.

Strands #298
‚ÄúRelative conjunction‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ

pretty straight forward.

plz avoid spoilers 'til we get below the fold.

I knew something was going on with THIS KISS, but I thought it had something to do with the letters ISS, as Sissy SPACEK also makes an appearance. I got it eventually.

It took much longer to let go of phasers at 37A. I was deeply committed to my mistake. I also had elope instead of KNOCK, so that area was the last to fall into place.

I thought this was a nice breezy puzzle with a fun theme for a recovery-type day for many folks. I liked the Diana Nyad clue as I have thought this as well but never seen it remarked upon. I had also thought that ‚Äúcheck‚Äù and ‚Äúatari‚Äù had to be announced by the player putting their opponent in that position, but Google tells me that isn‚Äôt the case. I guess that‚Äôs just something my dad did to help me when he was teaching me the game, but I never went on to play it regularly. I still have his board and stones though. He would have been 101 today (passed away over 14 years ago) and it was nice to have that little reminder of him in this puzzle.

I don't care how long you continue to use pop culture stuff like Faith Hill lyrics; you'll never induce me to listen or learn....
(Guess what was last to fall....)

Let us now speak of famous saves thanks to the crosses...

ERIK SATiE is getting some nice publicity these day, is he not?  

My brother-in-law was a student of/fan of the game of GO, but he never mentioned ATARi as the term for a win.  (He was interested in GO as a "winning strategy for the VietNam conflict.")  

Aaaaand here we are again with the supposed slang for the gumshoe/shamus:  TEC.  Boo.  You'd never catch anyone using that term on NCIS!

Such an uplifting puzzle! It sadly reminded me of the last time I tried to go up a ski lift. We ended our Alaskan cruise in Vancouver this summer and booked our group to go zip lining at Grouse Mountain. We excitedly got in line to take the gondola up. We were chatting about how relieved we were that we had been able to book a zip lining experience since the first one we booked in Ketchikan had been cancelled. After waiting 20 minutes, we realized that the line hadn‚Äôt moved and neither had the gondolas up the line. They were both stuck about midway up the mountain! We waited another 45 minutes before giving up and getting a refund. We found out from cruise friends that several people hiked down the mountain (a two hour trek) and those poor people on the gondolas were trapped for hours. 
Anyhow, thank you to Ella for this clever puzzle. I rather enjoyed it!!

I wish they would give less detailed/spoiler hunts in the blog for people who are new at crosswords and just want to know the method required for the puzzle. For example, if the rebus is needed or not. Things like that. I don't want answers to clues, just help with the format of solving.

I was distracted by RAISE THE BAR leaping the crevasse between 16A and 17A...and that's what you do when your SKI LIFT nears the peak. I got the trick eventually. Be careful driving in the South today; NC IS ICY.

I've always liked the "apt name" gags, and I feel like Nyad/naiad has been overlooked for too long. I recently learned that there is a celebrity chef named Andrew Gruel.

I recently spent a couple of months trying to master a classical guitar transcription of Gnossienne No. 1. It was a great transcription; it altered the key by a half-tone (fixable with a capo) and made very minor alterations for some things that are doable on piano but basically impossible on guitar, but otherwise very fairhful to the original. 

I can play it... sort of. My slurs got much, much better from trying. But the level of difficulty was making me dread and avoid practice and dislike the piece, so it was time to put it aside for a while. At least Satie's name is permanantly drilled into my head. That piece was the background music for every dream I had for weeks, too, even if it was a dream about changing out Honda fuel injectors (seriously).

I could not for the life of me remember the second letter of IRT, despite repeating "Just Another Girl On The..." to myself over and over, and couldn't remember ATARI, so that created my personal pseudo-Nantick and my only lookup.

I admire and enjoy a puzzle like this one, where I need the revealer to understand the theme, which then it helps me finish solving. For my money, that‚Äôs the best kind of puzzle.  

Thanks, Ella!

I once worked with a guy who was a RUBIK‚ÄôS CUBE speedsolver. He had outstanding

             ILLS
             K
MOTORS
Having just stopped skiing after 40 happy years enjoying the sport, I was glad to ride the lifts again.   I like that ‚Äúraise the bar‚Äù is snuck into the puzzle at 16 and 17 across.  Nice touch!

Wafted through this one without ever thinking about the theme---I'm well used to not knowing answers, filling on the crosses and guesses, then shrugging and moving on. I still don't know where the themed answers are!
Finally ground to a halt on the unguessable cross of 21A and 12D, involved New York trivia and (I imagine) some kind of mattress manufacturer.
Took it as an opportunity to learn a bit of NYC subway history, and eventually came back with the answer.

I just love dessert for breakfast after a holiday. My 3-layer gingerbread cake with marscapone-whipped cream frosting/filling was even more delicious when not eaten on top of a huge meal.
Of course I knew something was going on, but I filled in the whole grid before fully appreciating it. Thanks for the fun - haven't been skiing in years.
Happy Boxing Day!

Props to Erik Satie for inventing what he called "Digit drums", but let's not forget it was Tatiana Typewriter who said, "Hey, look what else this thing can do if we slide a piece of paper in here!"

I really liked this one, though I didn't get it right out of the gate. 

I have a memory like a, um, bad memory thing, but does anybody remember which puzzle constructor was a member of a typewriter band/orchestra?

This was one of those puzzles where I know there's a gimmick, but I go ahead and solve without fully understanding it, hoping it will become clear before too long.

I got PENCILS fairly early on in my solve, and I knew that was a poor answer to "Slim fitting bottom", but didn't click on what the right answer "had to be".  There's got to be something going on here, but what is it?

By the time I got down to the revealer, I also was figuring out that CASH IS wasn't a complete answer, and this time I knew that KING needed to be added to get a satisfactory answer.

But still it wasn't until after I had completed the puzzle that I was able to figure that Ms Hill's hit wasn't simply THIS, but needed a supplementary KISS via the SKI LIFT.

So, how would I rate this puzzle?  A little disappointing for a Thursday?
(But that's only because I spend too much time anticipating the joys of Thursday puzzles!)

Comments no longer appear when my puzzle is open - not since I updated the app.
Anyone else have this issue?
Any resolution?
The official NYT ‚Äúhelp desk‚Äù had none.  Ignored my request after I provided the additional info they requested.

This is my kind of puzzle, so I want to love it.  But the fact is that I found it a snooze because everything came in on its own without my having to even realize there was a theme, much less what it was.  The song that I never heard of could just as well have been titled "THIS",  and "CASH IS" could well have been a new expression from the generations that like to shorten absolutely everything for the purpose of texting.

Only at PENCILS should I have woken up, because PENCIL SKIRTS were a Thing when I was a teenager and I should have gone looking for them.  But I didn't.  Once I hit the revealer, I went back to look for all the SKI LIFTS, but by then the puzzle was over.

That rarest of things: A very good puzzle that I didn't appreciate.  Which is completely on me.  (Maybe if I hadn't been awakened and kept awake all night long by a banging radiator.  This has been going on all week.  Sure hope my super and handyman can solve the problem tomorrow...)

I also omitted to consider a theme and had the same experience as many on here. I also didn't leap to 'CASH IS KING' as it's not a phrase I've ever used. But I enjoyed solving the crossword clues and no complaints.
I just love puzzles like this! Feels unsolvable until you chip, chip, chip away at that theme. Great!
That was a nice winter theme. Seemed on the easier side for a Saturday. Timing was a little unfortunate (coincidence, obviously) in light of the horrific accident at Heavenly Valley on Christmas Eve.
TIL about Publius Servilius CASCA Longus, the first of the conspirators to stab Caesar.
Who‚Äôs Faith Hill üôÄ? Srsly, I read all the comments, but couldn‚Äôt find an explanation for 44A: Breaking the fourth wall = META. So, what is the fourth wall?
I find it interesting that Diana Nyad‚Äôs first name anagrams to ‚Äúnaiad‚Äù‚Ä¶ some may be ‚ÄúBorn to Run‚Äù, but she was obviously born to swim.

I didn't find this puzzle as easy as others did, but I did figure out the theme after I filled in the revealer. I thought it was clever and well constructed.

I think the main problem many commenters had was blithely accepting the almost-but-not-quite theme answers without considering there might be a trick... on a Thursday! I was surprised by this.

For me, figuring out the trick, theme, rebus, etc is part of the fun, and the puzzle isn't complete until I do.

Merry Christmas , Happy Chanukah and Peaceful Kwanzaa . 
The puzzles and this forum bring a delightful break to my world every day and for that I thank the NYT crossword team as well as all of you . May Wordplay lift your spirits and bring you the joy it brings to me .

Like several other people this morning -- as I see by skimming through previous comments -- I had no idea what Faith Hill's hit might be and had never been aware of the expression CASH IS KING, so THIS and CASH IS seemed perfectly logical to me. So did PENCILS, since that could easily be biz lingo for PENCIL SKIRTs. As a result, I breezed through the puzzle without any thought of a theme. When I saw the revealer, I checked the grid to see (yes, indeed, ho hum) three upside-down SKIs. They seemed like a pretty lame theme to me until I read Deb Amblen's notes and said, "Ooo!  I get it."  Nice puzzle.

Nice to learn where the name for the game company came from. And since that meant it isn't ONLY a brand name, I bounced over to see if Spelling Bee would accept it. Alas, no.
  And c'mon people: 5 more days left for a Chanukah puzzle; 6 for Kwanzaa. More candles! You can do it.
and of course so sad that 16A couldn't be WORLDPEACE or at least CEASEFIRE
Didn‚Äôt ‚Äúget‚Äù it until I read Deb‚Äôs column, but enjoyed the puzzle greatly, anyway! Thanks for everyone‚Äôs comments. Hope your holidays are full of peace and contentment.

An interesting, if simple, puzzle. I think the only work by Satie that included a typewriter is Parade, which includes a lot of other unconventional percussion instruments, including a starter's pistol, a jug of water sloshed around, tap shoes held in the hand, and a siren. But I think the oddest unconventional instrument is the bicycle, as played on Steve Allen's show by a young Frank Zappa in 1963. Check it: https://youtu.be/QF0PYQ8IOL4?si=jr-W5diVch2nl9hN
The Faith Hill song is called ‚ÄúThis Kiss,‚Äù not ‚ÄúThis.‚Äù Did I miss something?

I learned the word "tec" from "My Fair Lady."
Very interesting puzzle.

How tricky it must be
to take a puzzle with a trick,

keep it tricky enough 
to avoid a cacophony of
‚ÄúToo easy!‚Äù


while keeping it solvable enough 
to avoid a cacophony of
‚ÄúHated it!‚Äù

while keeping it fun enough to
avoid a cacophony of
‚ÄúMeh.‚Äù

The trickiest of tricky tricks‚Ä¶

This seemed more like a Wednesday, or even a Tuesday. Solved it fairly quickly without getting the theme until the Money talks clue. For those interested here's a YouTube video showing the unusual percussion instruments used in Parade by Erik Satie. https://youtu.be/aePrSe6DMsc?si=dl6w01fqOh7167Av

I solved this in the wee hours during an AFIB attack that kept me from sleep. I left a brief comment then. Now, I just circled back to see what everyone else thought of this puzzle. Very mixed reviews.

Many say it was too easy. I instead marvel at what went into constructing this puzzle. So although I solved in record time for me, I took a minute to stop and smell the roses.

Six weeks and counting until I have a procedure that should take care of my AFIB. Looking forward to doing the puzzles after a good night's sleep!
I figured this out despite the fact that the 3rd ski lift clue... "Money talks" should be "Cash is king." Instead with "peat bog" in for 42A, it reads "cash is kint" ü§î seems like a mistake to me.
Awful puzzle. Stupid clueing. Especially the Faith Hill clue. It should have been KISS not THIS.
Maybe I am just a dork, but I thought logomania was something everybody here suffers (?) from.

One of my professors hammered home a lesson that I have always tried to pass along. ‚ÄúThe composer started with a blank page.‚Äù This was in the context of music theory and history (unlike most schools, which teach theory in separate courses from history, my college insisted that the two never be separated). Nonetheless, the idea is essential: The writer is faced with a blank page/screen. The composer, blank staves. The set designer, an empty stage. The architect and builder, a cleared lot. What this means, its implication, is that everything imposed on that blank is meaningful, even when it is random. There are no throwaways. Every clue is meant to be read, even though one may get the finish music without having done so. Every circled square, shaded square, question mark, lack of symmetry, unusual symmetry, big huge shape that dominates the grid‚Ä¶is meant to be read, even though etc. Today‚Äôs comments section amounts to dozens of admissions of incuriosity. Fine; curiosity killed the cat. Curious cats take down Christmas trees. But why so few solvers are unwilling to maintain a curious mind - curious enough to pause and wonder - this is, for me, an eternal curiosity. I could probably fill in most puzzles (main, and especially mini) without reading all the clues while solving. But I never do. The constructor started with a blank page: every mark on it is meant to be read, understood, realized. R.I.P. Prof. Don Chittum https://obits.goldsteinsfuneral.com/donald-chittum-1

Deb's "an Across answer that completes the phrase" brought a great sense of relief that I might never have attained without her explanation. Two unfamiliar phrases and one new song title, but they made sense when I found them and explained some weird Acrosses.
Fun puzzle once you figure out the theme, but TEC was just LAM
I solved it by guessing I guess, as I never really got the theme til reading Wordplay ("This Kiss" helped though). I always like a gimme, but 58d is only valid in the NYT crossword puzzle.
I love it when I can just do a Thursday puzzle without having any clue that there is a twee precious theme. Just straightforward solving.

I got thrown by "the grid" in the clue.  I've kept up with the puzzle long enough to know that in lingo it refers to the puzzle in its entirety (is that synecdoche? Metonymy?).  But unless I stop to think that through, I assume grid just means, well, the grid, before I've filled in any words.  So I figured I was supposed to see three ski lift chairs in the black squares.  I would have preferred that the clue not use the insider jargon, and just say "puzzle."

If you follow Rex Parker, please check out my sweet pup Maxine in the holiday pet photos today. We lost her at just shy of 17 and a half right before this Thanksgiving. Last year the dorky stuff animals under the tree started moving and I caught this photo of her looking out. She was a character.

Typewriter percussion- anyone else think of Leroy Anderson and the Boston Pops ?

Wow, this has been a good week for Erik Satie--maybe he should demand a pay raise? No ski-lifts in Satie, but here's 27 seconds of sledding, from his suite "Sports and Diversions," performed for us by M. Pascal Rog√©: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oFkJ_0T5e5c ("Sports et Divertissements" (1914) is perhaps my favorite of Satie's works, as much for his beautiful, calligraphic scores; and the accompanying Art Nouveau illustrations by Charles Martin. It's in 21 movements, lasting about fifteen minutes in total, so the movements are very, very short. Some of the youtube videos of it feature the score or the illustrations, but not any which break the individual movements into separate videos. Pity.)

The theme is integrated incredibly . Loved it!

Solved the puzzle this morning before we hit the icy, foggy road home. Been in and out of dozing in the passenger's seat since. (Holidays are so exhausting!) 

But I still wanted to say what a pleasant puzzle this was! After I got the revealer I went to find the lifts right there in the places where I knew something was up (Ha! No pun intended!) Figured out PENCILSKIRTS because I knew it couldn't just be pencil. (Plus, I already had RUBIKSCUBE and SERTA.) So that helped me with R in ATARI and the other two, which I'd left open not knowing if there was a rebus or other trick. 

I know the CASHISKING saying when I saw it, but didn't know the Faith Hill song, so it certainly helped me that I had gotten the theme. And it made me smile! What else could I ask for? A real lift!

And so, just now, I found THIS KISS online and played it in the car. My white night had heard it before (he listens to country sometimes) but I don't recall every hearing it. Glad the puzzle included it because it's such a pretty song! I'm glad to know it now!

A PAY RAISE is always good but like many of you, I'm sure, my end of year wish is for peace on earth, Goodwill to all!

Barring that, maybe some peas on earth and a Gouda wheel for all....  üòâ

Such a nice fun puzzle! And no rebuses for anyone to complain about! A few Natiks for me (ERMA/ERIK SATIE; though I should have recognized from earlier this week!; and CASKA/SPACEK) but overall one of my favorite Thursdays in a long time!

Count me in with those who didn't get to the second level. Saw the ascending SKIs, of course. But:
1) I can hum the Faith Hill song, but couldn't swear that the title was simply "This."
2) For PENCILS, I thought something like slim fit jeans, which, albeit grammatically plural, constitute a singular bottom.
3) CASH IS was harder to justify, but I figured it was just an example of anapodoton; but then, I'm not always the sharpest tool.

(I tried posting this a couple hours ago, and kept getting an 
 "error" message, even though my link to Satie posted.)

@Steve L 2 out of 3 in my case. (I understood it once it was explained.) I have to say I prefer the kind of theme that helps me fill in the puzzle; this one didn't.
@Steve L Then it's a bad theme if that's the case

@Michael Weiland 

This theme definitely helped me.  I had THIS for the Faith Hill song, and knew it was supposed to be THIS KISS. But since everything else matched up in that area, I left it and moved on.  When I saw PENCILS and knew that the clue was for PENCIL SKIRT, that confirmed that something was fishy; I just didn't know what yet.

By the time I got to the revealer, SKI LIFTS, I saw that all three phrases, including CASH IS KING, had SKI in them, and it had something to do with lifting the phrases up at the end.

That's when I saw how the trick worked.

I would have finished the puzzle without using the revealer, but I wouldn't have understood it.
@Steve L Glad it worked for you. (You know Faith Hill better than I do.)

@Steven M.

As for me, I can't play golf.  But I don't blame the course for that.
@Steve L I highly doubt anybody is going to say they don't understand the theme after reading the column.

And they didn't put any obstructions in the easier path, just one three small sand traps. And half the people that play the hole didn't even realize there was a horseshoe bend, even after being told

@Steven M.

I believe the term you are looking for is "dogleg". I have seen holes that you can cut the corner like you say, but they are not cases of a poor design. You can always get the course layout from looking at the scorecard or signs on the holes so I think this analogy is a pretty stretched.

@Mr Dave Typically when you can cut the corner there's some risk involved (such as a water trap), but if the shortest path between points is a straight line, and there's no reason to use the dogleg instead of cutting the corner, then how is that a well designed hole?
@Shrike I'm pretty sure that has been said before about other puzzles so it's not inconceivable!

@Andrzej 

Based on prior experience, I am pretty sure there will be a number of people who have the three-step experience I described. I don‚Äôt believe most of the regulars will, but there will be many others who will. 

And most of those same people don‚Äôt read the existing comments before they leave their own comment, so I‚Äôm not worried about offending them. 

Anyway, three answers do not make sense without an understanding of the theme, so even if you can solve the puzzle without it, you can‚Äôt really understand it until you figure out how the idea of SKI LIFT works here.

Quite a few people were bewildered in one way or another, but apparently this one was mostly found to be relatively easy.

I frankly find it hard to tell these days what others are going to find easy or hard because I've already internalized what makes puzzles hard for necomers, and I don't notice it anymore.  My Thursday times this month have been within 90 seconds of one another.  None of them were rated Hard on xwstats.com.

I think you would find Go to be more challenging than any video game.  Just some white stones and some black stones and a board, but a killer amount of concentration, strategy, watchfulness, and nerve. The thrills are subtle, but they can be massive.

@Andrzej It seems you actually did find it challenging. The 'skilifts' clue requires us to find 3 clues where the full answer is revealed by a ski lift. Filling the grid can be considered completing the puzzle in one sense, but in another sense the puzzle's not complete until you actually solve per the theme. @Scott IRAS have been in NYT puzzles 136 times in the plural and 425 in the singular, so it‚Äôs one of those short fills you should just memorize as crosswordese, and wouldn‚Äôt have pinged editors as a Natick.

@Scott 
TEC is old slang for detective. In modern times, I've only seen it used to reference Detective Comics, which might feature LOIS Lane.

@Scott 
An IRA (or better yet, a Roth IRA) is a retirement savings account; this can be a huge help to people who do not earn Social Security benefits to any great degree but who need to save for future needs.  Speaking as a teacher (on the state Teacher Retirement Plan--which in Ohio in the 70's went bankrupt repeatedly) it made sense to augment the pitiful amount.  Taxes can be deferred until money is withdrawn (mandatory after a certain age) when the tax rate will be lower.

@Brandon Barr I recognize that I am a noob who does not know the shibboleths. I don't think that negates my desire for a puzzle that is solvable without knowing the entire history of the nyt crossword. I don't think my tone was harsh or in any way implying that I know better than the editors. Feedback is useful if you don't take it as an attack. 

Broadly speaking, I understand your point and even agree with it. Hard puzzles are hard and I'm not the smartest person in this room and I will learn the tricks with time. Fair enough. But calling me out for "pinging" the editors feels like a gatekeeper move.

@Heidi No, it‚Äôs not you, just another in the long line of themes that provide no help in solving. I‚Äôll bet 90%  of regular puzzlers don‚Äôt use Thursday themes to solve. At best they help me with one solution, but typically zero.

@Heidi

"Does that make me bad at solving, or does that make the theme bad at presenting itself?"

It's not and either/or situation.  It *does* mean that you were not curious enough to see why some of the answers didn't make sense.  

I didn't know the song, so THIS could have been the name, but PENCILS as a plural could not be the answer for the singular "bottom", so it became obvious that I had to do something to have an answer that made sense.  I found it to be an easy puzzle, so I didn't need the theme to fill in the boxes, but I did need it to have all of the answers have meaning.  

People unfamiliar with IRT, SERTA, KIA, and ATARI would definitely have benefited from understanding the trick.

I would prefer more of a challenge, but the trick did what it was supposed to do.  It required that you understand it in order to see what was going on with three of the answers.

According to the internet:
The fourth wall is an imaginary wall that separates the audience from the performers on stage. It's a key part of the audience's "suspension of disbelief" and is essential for enjoying works of fiction. 

The term "breaking the fourth wall" refers to when an actor acknowledges the audience, such as by speaking directly to them or noticing them. This breaks the boundary between the fictional world and the audience, and is a metafictional technique.

@GeoProf I've been somewhat surprised about the dislike exhibited here for TEC, which is a very familiar and completely standard abbreviation for me, and therefore a welcome gimme. The Collins on-line dictionary suggests it might be one of those vanishingly rare things, a NYT clue that's more familiar to speakers of British English: https://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/tec Perhaps the constructor reads a lot of British detective fiction?

Usage peaked (per ngram) in British and American English in the 50s and 60s, but, per xwordinfo, TEC has been showing up fairly steadily in the Times crossword for the past 60 years. So. Crosswordese, I'd say?
